divs: sighting detailsinvestigator beverly trout is submitting this sighting to cms. the investigation was done in 2003 by beverly trout, pam brackenbury, and clair canfield, and submitted to mufon headquarters at that time, but apparently did not get listed on cms. the reporting witness says he and a male friend were fishing at a farm pond not far from the tiny town of belknap, iowa, and about 10 miles nw of drakesville, iowa, at 7:30 p.m. on 10\7\2003, when they saw an estimated 12 to 20 white lights moving east to west, seemingly at high altitude, passing through the visual area of the constellation of virgo. lights were first observed at about 45 degrees up from the eastern horizon and last seen at about 15 degrees up from the western horizon. witnesses observed that the lights were switching positions very fast as they simultaneously moved forward, the cluster of lights all the while staying in the same area of their grouping. witness perceived them as white spots. that is, the lights did not seem to gleam or glisten; they were not shiny. size of lights seemed 3-4 times bigger than satellites they've observed in the night sky, and the lights all appeared to be the same size. witness saw the moon; it was at 20-25 degrees up from eastern horizon, but that it had nothing to do with the sighting. sunset on 10\7\03 was at 6:44 p.m., about 45 minutes before the sighting. weather per iowa state climatologist: temperature - 62 degrees f dewpoint - 55 degrees visibility - 10 miles wind - s at 8 mph it should be noted that mufon received two (2) other reports for the night of october 7, 2003, one from the fairfield, iowa, area for the same 7:30 p.m. time, and the same general description of a group of lights, and another sighting reported as approximately an 8:00 p.m. time frame of a group of lights at much lower altitude in the urbandale (des moines) area. none of the witnesses know the other witnesses.
Summary: Cluster of lights moving fast & changing positions as moved forward
trends: There have been no other sightings in Drakesville-Belknap area
This sighting has never been favorited.
